`prop-types` shouldn't be a peer dependency as per recommendation anyway: https://github.com/facebook/prop-types#how-to-depend-on-this-package

This is a workaround for libraries not following this recommendation (e.g. material-ui-pickers)

Was a transitive dependency of `size-limit` and `rollup-plugin-size-snapshot`
This is a migration/compat package only: https://emotion.sh/docs/ssr Not sure if a benchmark for those kind of packages is usefull? @oliviertassinari

Was transitive dependency due to:
- recharts
- react-draggable
- react-select
- react-virtualized

Wait, *emotion-server* package is legacy? How are we supposed to handle interoperability specificity?
Let's say I have a core component X that uses emotion but I also have a component Y that extends the style of X using styled-components. **If** I understand it correctly, styled-components with inject the CSS in the head when emotion will inject the CSS in the body. The SSR output specificity will be wrong (inverted). cc @tkh44.
It's a peer dependency of these packages? Why do we need to install it?
Not legacy. Just "compatibility and migration purposes". I don't think that applies to the benchmark in question. It would however apply to the use case you mentioned I think.
Well spotted! We should fix that.
No it's a peer dependency of `notisstack`. `notisstack` would fail if we would remove the packages I mentioned.
And it is already installed. We're not adding any new packages to the bundle in this PR
I'm fascinated by the number of yarn warnings we have, and yet, they are all false positive (everything works).

> I'm fascinated by the number of yarn warnings we have, and yet, they are all false positive.

You can look at them like a built-in `import/no-extraneous-dependencies` lint rule. All of the warnings I fixed in this PR are indeed defects. They're only not actual bugs because of transitive dependencies. As soon as we would remove unrelated packages that create these transitive dependencies we would face actual bugs in our code. Therefore they're not false positives unless you think that `import/no-extraneous-dependencies` is not a useful rule.

Some are also just underspecified peer dependencies. The `jss` plugins for instance all work with the alpha for our usage. But maybe the full test suite of these plugins is not passing for the jss alpha which is why the peer is pinned to a stable version.

@eps1lon You are right, it's hiding core problems. Now, let's imagine people who are pressured by a deadline, and don't have the time to look closer what they must think about yarn warnings: it's just noise. I believe many people have learned to ignore them. We shouldn't encourage this!

My main issue is that you don't have a place were you can ignore those warnings (and preferably include an explanation why).

This was pretty annoying during the hooks alpha where basically every package triggered peer dependency warnings. Spotting an actual warning in 30+ warnings that do not cause harm is very hard. I would've liked to have some sort of warning whitelist where I can tell that this is fine because this alpha is stable enough to not cause any harm (or ran integration tests etc). All of this is responsibility of the dev in control of the package.json

Yarn maintainers are at least aware of this issue: https://github.com/yarnpkg/yarn/issues/4064#issuecomment-319399922

peer dependencies are not in a perfect spot but it's all we have so we should make the best of it. Since we have things like tree-shaking I rather have an unused package in my package.json and no warnings than a warning that I just ignore.

Is there a possibility that it might be intended that no `stylesheet` is present?
What is the use case for this?
Why do we need this?
We have some code before that assume the `styleSheet` is always present. This change is embracing it fully.

Commenting the diff would make two tests fail:
```
24 passing (2s)
  2 failing

  1) withStyles
       integration
         should run lifecycles with no theme:

      AssertionError: expected { root: 'Hook-root-vy1bts' } to deeply equal { root: 'Empty-root-vy1bts' }
      + expected - actual

       {
      -  "root": "Hook-root-vy1bts"
      +  "root": "Empty-root-vy1bts"
       }

      at Context.deepEqual (packages/material-ui-styles/src/withStyles.test.js:80:14)

  2) withStyles
       classname quality
         should use the displayName:

      AssertionError: expected 'Hook' to equal 'a'
      + expected - actual

      -Hook
      +a

      at Context.strictEqual (packages/material-ui-styles/src/withStyles.test.js:219:14)
```

withStyles uses the display name to provide a meta option.
In case somebody do `useTheme(props)` or else.
Shouldn't it just override the `name` then? It seems like the `name` and `meta` option are doing the same.

Yes I saw that. My question is why would we guard against this? The hook didn't have an argument previously, nor did `withTheme`. 

Different angle: Why do we only warn here at runtime that a nullary function was called with a single argument? I looks like that using a type checker like flow or typescript would be the first choice if somebody would be interested in warnings for wrong number of arguments.

The `name` value is human picked. The `meta` is inferred. The name can have a strong implication on the generated class names in production, the meta is only used for improving the debugging experience.
Can we change the name of `meta` then? It's a pretty generic term. What speaks against using `inferredName`?
Ok, let's kill it.

That is not correct. You didn't specify dependencies in the second argument to `useEffect`. The effect will be executed after every render (as well as this cleanup).
Not incorrect, just not optimal.  :D

No it's simply not correct. That function will execute not only on unmount but also before every other effect execution. In this case the effect will scheduled after every render. This is similar to componentDidUpdate +  componentWillUnmount. 

Doesn't matter if it is not optimal. You either change the effect hook so that it only runs on mount or you change the name of the cleanup function.

> itemsClient is scoped to the render function of that component.

Uh, whoops!

> No it's simply not correct.
[...]
> change the name of the cleanup function

Oh, the function name! Why didn't you just say so? It might as well be called Bob, (or be anonymous) for all I care. The name (if it is going to have one) is correct for its intended purpose, just not the way it's currently called. (Already fixed my local branch).
It sounds like we might be able to get rid of react-event-listener :) https://bundlephobia.com/result?p=react-event-listener@0.6.6.

> I suppose this was discussed privately?

It was mentioned in the other TOC PR discussion [here](https://github.com/mui-org/material-ui/pull/14520#issuecomment-463403753).

> Could you add at least a short summary what the problem was.

The clue is in the title :D 

The current regex doesn't work for unicode, due to \W stripping non ascii characters, so instead we filter common non-word characters 'manually'. The replacement regex is list of symbols to filter. Nothing more complicated than that.

> I also tried to use a ref so that `itemsClient = getItemsClient(itemsServer)` in `useEffect()` is only updated when the `contents` prop changes, but without success:

This is what the second argument for `useEffect` is for. Effects are only executed if one of the values in the second argument changes.

@matthewjwhitney Thanks, I'm moving forward, I'm happy to take your feedback anytime you can :).

@eps1lon What do you think of the scroll behavior when clicking on a TOC?

It's kind of slowing me down and makes me sick to see the page move. I have to unfocus the page, wait for the end of the scroll animation and focus back to read the content I'm interested in.
I've already removed it. I don't suffer from motion sickness, so I hadn't noticed. If there are n% of users who do, that's a problem.
This started as a quick restyle of the TOC, and escalated from there!

I like the transition and that it's more obvious where you are in the text. But I personally like my table of contents complete. I would not make those collapsible. I think we have enough vertical space to display everything.

I'm trying to find examples of great documentation. Few have a TOCs: developers.google.com, getbootstrap.com, docker.com, most don't have it. After looking at them, I think that we should keep the current logic:
- The TOCs collapse creates a distraction when reading the documentation.
- The TOCs collapse prevents to see all the subsection up-front.
- I don't have any strong case against the hash change based on the scroll. But given none of the documentation I could benchmark do it, I would rather not do it either (maybe I have haven't looked at enough documentation ü§î). Just so people have a consistent behavior between the different documentation they have to browse when working on one project.

One thing I think that we should work on regarding the TOCs: **i18n support**, it's quite a broken right now in Chinese ‚úåÔ∏è.

> I personally like my table of contents complete. I would not make those collapsible It helps to see at a glance what the main sections are. From there, if you choose, you can pick a subsection. It's the same thing we do with the nav drawer. It also helps with something you mentioned elsewhere - users skipping over important foundational knowledge. If you can more easily skip straight to a subsection without first visiting the main section, you are more likely to miss something important. In any event, since neither you nor Olivier like it, lets drop that enhancement. Perhaps there's an alternative styling for main vs sub-section that would help make the distinction.

> It's the same thing we do with the nav drawer.

If we had the vertical space I'd be happy to skip collapsing.

> It also helps with something you mentioned elsewhere - users skipping over important foundational knowledge.

IMO this change would hurt it. That's why I thought this particular change wasn't good. Your example perfectly illustrates that: We have a level 1 section about SVG icons but also a section about SVG icons under accessibility. I would need to manually click through those to find the part I'm interested in.

Wikipedia is doing the some. The TOC is either fully expanded or collapsed. I think that's a pretty strong argument for fully expanded TOCs.

> Perhaps there's an alternative styling for main vs sub-section that would help make the distinction.

Maybe add numbers to the indentation to make the distinction between section and subsection clearer?

> none of the documentation I could benchmark do it

Here's one you might be familiar with! ü§£ 
https://material.io/design/components/app-bars-bottom.html

Doing this means that when someone is referencing the documentation, the URL pinpoints the specific section. (If anything, it bugs me when there isn't a specific enough id. Having to say "go to this URL, then scroll down to XXX is a PITA for everyone.)

(Yes, we have the '#' icon, but it's easy to miss, or to forget to click before copying the URL.)

> Maybe add numbers to the indentation to make the distinction between section and subsection clearer?

At one point I had ' - ' in front of subsection titles, but because of wrapped headings, it looked odd, so I dropped it (although there is almost certainly a CSS solution to that which preserves the indentation for subsequent lines). 

Perhaps rather than making the currently selected section or sub section bold, we reserve it for top level sections. The highlight should be enough by itself to show the currently selected section, so long as contrast doesn't suffer without the emboldening.

> Here's one you might be familiar with! ü§£

@mbrookes I shouldn't have said "none" :). Then maybe it's just me spending too much time on their documentation, I dislike the way it's structured. They have disabled the headlines click to get the anchor. Yeah, I think that we should use this documentation as an example of what we shouldn't do üôÜ‚Äç‚ôÇÔ∏è. I'm curious on the ratio % count of docs website using manual anchor links vs automatic. As somebody often linking documentation anchor, I personally prefer "being in control".

> Doing this means that when someone is referencing the documentation

Then why so few documentation websites use this approach? I think that it's because you don't know if a person is going to link the whole page or a subsection, you let him choose. Most of the time, they link the whole page, so you optimize for the majority. It's also an incentive for us to split large documentation pages. 

> I would need to manually click through those to find the part I'm interested in.

@eps1lon üíØ 

---

IMHO we shouldn't try to put too many thoughts into how the TOCs work. I think that a lot of documentation, older & more used than our have spent a lot of time on the problem, I would just copy what the majority do. "The majority is right", I think that it applies in this case. It's what I have tried to do when implementing the TOCs.

> Maybe add numbers to the indentation to make the distinction between section and subsection clearer?

We could increase the left padding a bit? Take Antd https://ant.design/components/anchor/, they have a wider gap.

> > Doing this means that when someone is referencing the documentation
> 
> Then why so few documentation websites use this approach?

To be fair: This is probably skewed because it's the default behavior of the docs software. 

I think having the anchor automatically update is a nice feature. It doesn't require knowledge about position of anchor links or if one even exists. I would even prefer if the anchor links where visible by default.

@oliviertassinari > I think that it's because you don't know if a person is going to link the whole page or a subsection, you let him choose. Fair point, although I would argue that it's easier to remove an anchor than to remember to add it in. > We could increase the left padding a bit? The challenge we have there is that we have some long headings that are already cramped. We would probably need to make the TOC wider to compensate. I'll try it and see. > Take Antd [...], they have a wider gap. I notice that for their docs, they truncate long headings, which doesn't work well. And they don't display sub-headings at all. @eps1lon > I would even prefer if the anchor links where visible by default. I personally think that detracts from the appearance of the docs: (unless perhaps we made it very low contrast). Nobody has commented on the styling, which was the original purpose of the PR (before I started to uncover other issues, and got carried away with adding features). I'm not tied to any particular styling, I just didn't think the link style underline was working well, so if anyone has other ideas I'm listening.

```suggestion
    "build:es": "echo 'skip es folder'",
```

`&& exit 0` is a noop. 
- If the first command returned 0 then we return `exit 0` => same exit code
- If the first command return non-zero we won't reach `exit 0` => same exit code

`Array.prototype.find` is not supported in IE 11 an caused the crash

I vote for using `hidden` over `aria-hidden`. https://developer.paciellogroup.com/blog/2012/05/html5-accessibility-chops-hidden-and-aria-hidden/. One of the implication of this attribute is to set `display: none`. This 1. Make the behavior consistent when `unmountOnExit: true` is used. 2. It removed the need for the custom existed style: simpler. 3. in a future version of React, it indicates that the content render can be deferred.

I would prefer `hidden`. The current approach would be non-breaking. 

Using `hidden` would. While it would be consistent with `unmountOnExit: true` or `mountOnEnter: true` it's inconsistent with the current default values. It would break a lot of layouts (including our docs, ExpansionPanel etc).

I think we should come up with an API to control that behavior. The `hidden` heuristic is for Concurrent mode only so it's not that important at the moment. I would like that feature for v4 though in case this requires some breaking change.

> It would break a lot of layouts (including our docs, ExpansionPanel etc).

I have tried the ExpansionPanel, it won't break it. The demo headers can be fixed by adding a `<div style={{ flexGrow: 1 }} />` element. Anything else? I have looked at the Bootstrap animations, they set display: none when the component is hidden.
I think that we should move forward in this direction.

Rename it to `classes.hidden`? `exited` might be misleading.

We have a problem with the focus logic. A visibility hidden element can't receive the focus. Now, the problem is that our Modal, Dialog, Menu components don't wait for the transition to start to focus the children, hence it's not working. The Firefox 52 test fail is just a symptom, you could see that the dialog autofocus logic was broken too on Chrome latest. There is no quick win here, it's a difficult problem to solve. I think that we can think of a solution handle:
- The focus accessibility issue of #14465
- The API #14376
- Some transition components would be better off with visibility hidden while some other with display none. We need to figure it out.

> We have a problem with the focus logic. A visibility hidden element can't receive the focus. Now, the problem is that our Modal, Dialog, Menu components don't wait for the transition to start to focus the children, hence it's not working. There is no quick win here, it's a difficult problem to solve. 

I think the issue is that those components set the `in` prop to true while simultaneously using an imperative focus in the DOM. They would need to wait for the changes to be commited to the DOM and then focus i.e. set the prop in the render phase and then focus in e.g. `useEffect`. Currently we set the prop and focus during render which is causing the issue.

The good thing is that this was always an issue that might've caused some subtle bugs. The bad thing is that we also need to fix dependent components.

@oknechirik It's a great first pull request on Material-UI üëåüèª. Thank you for working on it!
@eps1lon Thank you for the accessibility link!

@erichodges You are right, the current implementation definitely requires a child element **when open**, only when open. This is allowing people to do: ```jsx {this.state.open ?
Text in a modal Duis mollis, est non commodo luctus, nisi erat porttitor ligula.
: null} ``` The change you are suggesting prevents this approach. I still think that we should support it! The render method has a defensive check for it: ```js function getHasTransition(props) { return props.children ? props.children.props.hasOwnProperty('in') : false; } ```

> @erichodges You are right, the current implementation definitely requires a child element **when open**, only when open.

I don't understand what that use case achieves? The `Modal` should take care of its children. You shouldn't have to do conditional rendering inside the component. 

It goes completely against what things like `Suspense` are doing for you. We want to get away from that imperative conditional rendering logic and be as declarative as possible. The implementation (modal = material-ui, suspsense = react core) should do the imperative work.
I still think that adding an explicit throw can help in any case, no matter if we make the children required or not. It's better than a "undefined doesn't have a props key" exception.

> @eps1lon Some people don't need the transition. The approach I have linked improves the performance when the modal is closed. **It skips the rendering of the whole Modal children**, depending on your app, it can be a large tree.

[That is not true](https://codesandbox.io/s/9p8z43qq4). At least not for latest react and I'm fairly certain that this was always the case for react. The elements are lazily evaluated.

> It's not related to Suspense. 

Motivation is the same.

@eps1lon We always have to make a bold statement with you üòÑ.

> Motivation is the same.

Sure, people want fast applications.

> [That is not true](https://codesandbox.io/s/9p8z43qq4).

You are using the documented approach in the performance section of the modal documentation. Yes, this approach is valid. 

I'm proposing the following:
- We warn upfront for missing children, so people don't have to interact with the UI to get the warning: we are lazy.
- We encourage a simple approach that works with transition & non-transition people to work around performance: the documented approach. https://codesandbox.io/s/9p8z43qq4 & https://material-ui.com/utils/modal/#performance.
- We add an explicit throw error so people have a better idea of what's wrong. (prototypes warning + explicit runtime error).

This flag was needed because CI failed while locally I succeeded. The only reliable solution was to build with the lock and keep it up to date. My suggestion was to automate dependency updates with renovate or greenkeeper instead, but Olivier didn't want the PR noise and I can definitely understand that sentiment.

Given my theory about the cache, and what was not answered by @eps1lon in that PR was if we still need the offline cache hack he added? That is what I suggest the only diff between local and CI....and my inclination is to remove this offline cache hack and simplify the cache config.

My builds run on circleci and I need no such hack, perhaps we drop the offline cache and drop the frozen lockfile?

The offline-cache is used because the network in CircleCI is not reliable. We had repeated build failures because the network timed out. We didn't have any network issues after this change. 

I didn't explain this because it is/was just a reiteration of the original [PR/commit message](https://github.com/mui-org/material-ui/pull/12763) for this change. However you did not explain why this was suddenly not necessary anymore. Do you have a source that described the original problem and that it was fixed?

> This flag was needed because CI failed while locally I succeeded.

That is just not a valid explanation. I expect more from contributors that open issues so if I ask you explicitly I expect that you follow a similar schema: "What did you do? What did you expect? What happened? Why do you think this is a bug?"

Following the original commit history it looks like an issue with a dependency of `dtslint` and more specifically how some yarn versions handle github dependencies. This is almost certainly cause by different versions of yarn i.e. a (fixed) bug in `yarn`. It does not follow from this that we should change how our CI works.

I'm more than happy to understand why having a frozen lockfile in CI is a good thing when not communicating that to our devs results in different dependency trees for local development and CI.

A documented configuration setting that is [used how documented is a hack](https://yarnpkg.com/blog/2016/11/24/offline-mirror/)?

We were using babel-node so we could write the source with es modules. I'm curious why you want to change this point.

`babel-node`:
- imposes a runtime overhead
- makes debugging harder if sourcemaps are not setup properly

it enables in our case:
- es modules which don't provide any value in the node runtime

My motivation was more: let's write the same code everywhere even if it's not the best tool for the job. The difference is negligeable. Simplicity first.

I didn't know about the source map issue.

Let's defer this to a different PR then. I'll change to `babel-node` tomorrow.

I would like to get rid of it completely. Since node 8 already has `async/await` it doesn't add any value at the moment.
In some way, we might always need Babel. The JavaScript language is moving. Won't we need it too if we start using TypeScript?

Browser and node are two different targets. We use our node scripts only internally so requiring something like node 10 or 12 is not that big of a deal. Doing so removes the babel requirement apart from the latest es features and there is no big value gained by using those features.

Typescript for our node scripts is somewhat overkill at the moment. I think you're mixing various concepts here: `babel-node` has nothing to with our components (or Ssr). It's currently only used to use es modules in our node scripts that provide no benefit in the node runtime.

Tried to revert but `babel-node` has some issues with transpiling code that is outside the cwd which is common in a monorepo: https://github.com/babel/babel/issues/7566

This is fixable with the `ignore` flag but then we have to maintain those contents for every require and TL;DR: The amount of maintenance and time this adds to enable es modules in the node runtime (which don't add anything) is not worth it. At least it hasn't been shown to me.

We can revisit this once we need to transpile this dev script at runtime.
I have revisited a bit the implementation. Let me know what you think.
We had an issue with `yarn lerna run build:copy-files`.
Do with the PR as you please. I can't work on this if you refuse to provide a rationale.

Now, the difference between babel-node vs using node doesn't outweigh the benefit of letting you pick what you think work best for the use case. I have reverted the changes. I have focused my attention on the logic, migrating some of the logic to the async / await syntax. I shouldn't have pushed force on your fork branch. I'm sorry. I'm cautious since making changes will affect translations @mbrookes  ?

@joshwooding How funny - at the same moment you submitted that comment, I was submitting a suggested change to the wording, similar to yours. (Yours is even better).

Regarding the translations - now that we have multiple languages underway, I have a better understanding of how these changes are treated.

A small change will invalidate translations for the entire sentence in which it is made (i.e. the translation will revert to English). However, the original translation is offered as an option to translators, showing a percentage match with the original. This can then be modified, rather than starting from scratch. 

So, while it is initially harmful to the translated docs, the burden on translators is minimal. (The challenge we have is the small number of translators relative to the size of the docs, and frequency of changes.)

On balance, I would prefer that we accept changes that clarify the English documentation (particularly since not all English docs contributions are from Native speakers). "It's" / "its" is grammatically incorrect, but inconsequential relative to the potential impact on 7 translations. Your proposed simplification (please go ahead and edit mine) is worth it.
I‚Äôll find some time tomorrow to read the page again and suggest more changes
